title: Solvothermal synthesis, thermal and adsorption properties of metal-organic frameworks Zn and CoZn(DPB)
text: Porous metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) constitute an important class of hybrid materials. These compounds have attracted attention because of their large pore size, high surface area, and thermal, magnetic, optical and catalytic properties [

]. According to the pore size, the porous materials are classified into: microporous (pore diameter 0.2–2.0 nm), mesoporous (pore diameter 2.0–50.0 nm) and macroporous (pore sizes exceeding 50.0 nm). Microporous and macroporous materials are widely used as adsorbents [
]. Coordination polymers or metal-organic frameworks are polymeric materials with frameworks formed from organic bridging ligands and metal ions, and these compounds have unique features [
]. One of the most important features of MOFs is the ability to tailor the material’s properties by appropriate choice of the staring materials [

]. The most important part in the design of the metal-organic frameworks is the organic linker. The linkers are organic polyfunctional ligands that coordinate with multiple metal centers forming one-, two- or three-dimensional polymeric structures [

]. Unique functionalities have been found in metal-organic frameworks, in particular the porous properties of these compounds. Much attention has been attracted to the porous MOFs because of their importance in creation of nanometer-sized pore size, the discovery of new phenomena and their commercial applications in heterogeneous catalysis, as well as separation and storage of gases [
In this work, we prepared four new mononuclear and hetero-binuclear MOFs derived from the reaction of 1,4-bis[(3,5-dimethyl)pyrazole-4-yl]benzene (H

DPB) with zinc nitrate or mixture of zinc and cobalt nitrates by solvothermal method from dimethylformamide (DMF) or ethanol. The porosity of the obtained MOFs was studied by nitrogen adsorption, and the surface area was calculated.
This work has some advantages as it presents new thermally and mechanically stable porous MOFs, which can be prepared with large amounts by simple technique.

All materials were obtained from commercial suppliers and were used without further purification. Elemental analysis was carried out on Flash 2000 CHNS Analyzer from Thermo Scientific. Thermogravimetric analyses were carried out on a Shimadzu-TGA-50H equipment by using alumina sample holder and sample masses 6.62, 6.41, 6.07 and 6.56 mg for compounds (1), (2), (3) and (4), respectively. The nitrogen flow rate and heating were 20 cm
, respectively. D2 PHASER Bruker diffractometer was used to perform XRD data by using CuKα radiation (

adsorption isotherms were measured, at 77 K, on a Micromeritics Tristar 3000 volumetric instrument. Mattson 5000 FTIR Spectrometer was used to measure the infrared spectra as KBr disks. Mechanical stress tests were performed on 100 mg sample by applying pressure, up to 0.2 GPa (2 tons cm

DPB) was suspended in 30 mL absolute ethanol at 120 °C, followed by the addition of 0.13 gm (0.05 mmol) of the hydrated Zn(NO

O in 10 mL absolute ethanol. Then, the reaction mixture was refluxed for 2 h. A white precipitate was separated on reflux. The precipitate was filtered, washed with ethanol and kept to dry under vacuum (yield = 0.13 gm, 83 % based on the ligand). Elemental analysis: calcd (%) for Zn(C
DPB) was dissolved in hot DMF (10 mL, 110 °C) after being cooled to room temperature, Zn(NO

O (0.30 gm) was added. The resulting mixture was placed in a heating tube which was heated at 120 °C for 10 h. The isolated white product was filtered off, washed several times with DMF and suspended in methylene chloride overnight followed by centrifugation and decantation (yield = 0.11 gm, 72 % based on the ligand). O and 0.072 gm of the hydrated Co(NO

O in 10 mL absolute ethanol. The reaction mixture was refluxed at 120 °C for 2 h. The formed violet precipitate was washed with ethanol and kept to dry under vacuum (yield = 0.19 gm, 84 % based on the ligand). Elemental analysis: calcd (%) for Co
DPB) was dissolved in hot DMF (10 mL, 110 °C) after being cooled to room temperature, Zn(NO
O (0.3 gm) was mixed with 0.3 gm of Co(NO

O and dissolved in the ligand solution with stirring. The resulting mixture was placed in a heating tube which was heated at 120 °C for 10 h. White product was isolated, filtered off, washed several times with DMF and suspended in methylene chloride overnight followed by centrifugation and decantation (yield = 0.11 gm, 72 % based on the ligand).

], was used as implemented in Endeavour 1.7b [
]. The structure was solved by the simulated annealing technique. Pawley refinements were used to carry out the final refinements.
Molecular geometry was optimized by molecular mechanics and the semiempirical AM1 methods using the hyperchem series of programs [
]. The low-lying conformer was investigated by molecular mechanics technique (MM+ force field) then optimized at the semiempirical AM1 (Polak-Ribiere), RMS 0.01 kcal [
The solvothermal reaction of Zn(II) and Co(II) nitrates with the ligand (H

DPB) in ethanol or DMF results in the formation of MOFs with general formulae M(DPB) (M = Zn(II) or Co(II)Zn(II) and (DPB) = the anionic form of the ligand 1,4-bis[(3,5-dimethyl)pyrazole-4-yl]benzene). The formation of mononuclear and hetero-binuclear MOFs is represented by the following equation:
are white fine crystalline materials, while compounds
are violet powders. All the four compounds are stable in air and insoluble in most common solvents, but partially soluble in DMSO and DMF. The solvothermal reaction of Zn(II) and Zn(II)Co(II) with (H
DPB) in ethanol at 120 °C led to the formation of coordination compounds of the formulae Zn(DPB)

, isolated as microcrystalline powder in good yield. Other MOFs with the same general formulae were obtained by carrying out the reaction solvothermally in DMF for 12 h, at 120 °C as the case of compounds
The spectra of all the compounds reveal bands in the regions 1374–1380 and 1312–1320 cm
assigned to ν C–N. These bands exist at lower wavenumber compared with their positions in the ligand. The bands in the region 1626–1660 cm

assigned to ν C=N were shifted to higher wavenumbers compared with their positions in the ligand. These observations indicate the participation of the pyrazole group in coordination with the metal ions through the nitrogen atoms. The band at 1029 cm
attributed to ν N–N in the free ligand is shifted to higher wavenumber in the spectra of all compounds, supporting the participation of the pyrazole nitrogen in bonding [
Because of the difficulty in finding a suitable DFT basis function for the polynuclear metal complexes [
], molecular mechanics and the semiempirical AM1 methods were used to optimize the molecular geometry of Zn(DPB)

. A rapid investigation of the geometries of the suggested structures was done by the molecular mechanics and the semiempirical AM1 method. The semiempirical method is compared well to values obtained at the ab initio level using medium-size basis sets [

The cause of the difference between the observed bond lengths and angles from X-ray structure and that obtained from AM1 calculations was attributed to the effect of hydrogen bonding and neighbor molecules which were not taken into consideration for the theoretically calculated parameters.

Thermal analysis gives important information about the thermal stability and the strength of the bonds. To investigate the thermal stability of the synthesized compounds, the thermal measurements (TG) were carried out from 25 up to 1000 °C (Fig.
shows a loss of hydrated water molecules from 29 to 160 °C (mass loss 7.0 %, calcd 7.3 %). No further mass loss from compound
up to 320 °C was observed. The first step of decomposition of the solvent free form of compound
takes place from 320 to 431 °C, corresponding to the loss of (CH
pyrazole (mass loss 20.7 %, calcd 19.5 %). The next step attributed to the loss of (CH
pyrazole and benzene moieties. This step occurs in the range 431–709 °C (mass loss 36.1 %, calcd 35.0 %).
shows that it loses the solvent in the temperature range 30–190 °C, and then it loses the organic linker in two successive steps from 200 to 634 °C (mass loss 58.1 %, calcd 60.0 %). Compound
loses its crystallinity on evacuation at 180 °C and changes to amorphous.
loses the solvent molecules in the range 35–130 °C, it loses the organic ligand in the temperature range 340–500 °C (mass loss 65.4 %, calcd 66.2 %).
shows that it loses the host molecules in the temperature range from 30 to 219 °C. The organic linker starts to decompose from 220 to 694 °C in two steps.
From the above discussion, it could be concluded that after the host molecules have been lost, compounds
remain stable up to ca 320 °C, while compounds
remain stable up to ca 200 °C. Compounds
The polymer is considered as a thermostable material when it loses 10 % of its mass in the temperature range 400–450 °C [

seems to be the most stable among them, and it is closer to be thermally stable. According to their thermal stabilities, the present compounds could be arranged in the following order:
Mechanical stress tests were carried out on grounded samples by applying pressure, up to 0.2 GPa (2 tons cm
). The mechanical stability test of compound
remains practically unaffected after the application of pressures up to 0.2 GPa, which is indicative of the framework rigidity. Compound
lost its crystallinity on applying pressures up to 0.2 GPa and turned to amorphous.
One of the most important applications of MOFs is the gas sorption. The importance of gas sorption properties of MOFs comes from its ability to uptake fuel gases such as methane and hydrogen [
]. To establish the attainment of permanent porosity after removal of solvent molecules, the measurements of gas adsorption are essential [
has been confirmed by adsorption of N
at 77 K, and the apparent surface area has been calculated [
]. To remove the solvent molecules, the sample was subsequently dried at 130 °C for 6 h. On evacuation, at 180 °C compounds
